awd_abstract_narration:
The concept of a group in mathematics grew out of the notion of symmetry. The symmetries of an object in nature or of a theoretical construct can be encoded by a group, which itself carries important information about the structure of the object. Representation theory allows one to study groups in a uniform way via their actions on vector spaces, which model common ways groups act in applications. Representation theory has been a central topic in mathematics for more than a century and has important applications in physics and chemistry, particularly in quantum mechanics and the theory of elementary particles. Finite groups and their representations have important applications in coding theory and cryptography, and play an important role in modern computation and digital communications. This project aims to advance understanding in the representation theory of finite groups and in a number of applications. 

In more detail, this project focuses on several important questions in group representation theory and its applications. It ties together different areas of mathematics, such as finite groups and algebraic groups, permutation groups, probabilistic group theory, group cohomology, combinatorics, vertex operator algebras, and algebraic geometry, with representation theory as the main unifying ingredient. Many of the questions addressed in the project come up naturally in the study of group representations, and others are motivated by applications. The investigator will study several problems along the lines of the global-local principle, including conjectures of McKay, Alperin, Brauer, and others that extend and generalize classical results in the representation theory of finite groups. The investigator also intends to study classification of modular representations of low dimension and to develop a theory of character level, with the goal of establishing strong bounds on character values for finite quasisimple groups. It is anticipated that the results can be applied to study Aschbacher's conjecture on subgroup lattices and the Kollar-Larsen problem on exterior powers, Miyamoto's problem, problems on random walks and anti-concentration, representation varieties of Fuchsian groups, word map distributions and Waring-type problems for quasisimple groups, refinements of Holt's conjecture on second cohomology groups, and representations of quasisimple groups with special properties.

Project outcomes of the research grant DMS-1840702

The NSF grant DMS-1840702 (originally DMS-1665014)  
focuses on several important problems in representation theory of finite groups, and their applications in permutation groups, probabilistic  group theory, group cohomology, combinatorics, number theory, and algebraic geometry.  Among the major outcomes of the PI's research
within this grant, we mention

-- solution of the probabilistic Waring problems for finite simple groups, published in Annals of Math. 2019;

-- proof of strong exponential character bounds for finite groups of Lie type, published in Acta. Math. 2018 for split Levi
subgroups, and its extension to non-split Levi subgroups, published in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 2020;

-- word-theoretic extensions of classical theorems of Burnside and Feit--Thompson, published in Inventiones Math. 2018 (this paper was awarded
the  2021 Kalman Prize of the New Zealand Mathematical Society);

-- foundations of level theory and character bounds for characters of finite classical groups of type A, published in Forum of Math. Pi 2020;

-- characterizations of fields of values of odd-degree complex characters (and their analogues for odd primes $p$), published in
Forum of Math. Pi 2021 and Advances of Math. 2019;

-- determinations of possible structures of monodromy groups of $l$-adic hypergeometric sheaves, and explicit realizations of sporadic and classical
simple groups as monodromy groups of hypergeometric sheaves, published in a series of papers in Advances in Math. 2019, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 2020,
GAFA 2021, Proc. London Math. Soc. 2021, and Cambridge J. Math. 2021;
 
-- solution of the irreducible restriction problem for modular representations of symmetric and alternating groups in small characteristics,
published in a series of papers in  Representation Theory 2020, Math. Z. 2019, Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. 2020, and Advances in Math. 2020;

-- characterization of Brauer blocks with a single simple module, published in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 2019; and

-- applications of character bounds in the study of representation varieties of Fuchsian groups and random generation of finite groups of Lie type, published in Advances in Math. 2020, and in the study of random walks and McKay graphs of simple groups, published in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc. 2021.
 

The PI's research within this grant has led to a better understanding of basic properties, in
particular linear representations and also permutation representations, of finite groups, especially finite groups of Lie type, long-standing conjectures about them, and their interrelations with other areas of mathematics. It has also led to significant advances in a number of applications in structural and cohomological group theory, combinatorics, Galois theory, l-adic local systems, algebraic geometry, and number theory. Results obtained within this grant have helped train three graduate students.

The PI's results have been lectured at many national and international conferences, including

-- an invited 45-min lecture at the International Congress of Mathematicians 2018, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Aug. 1--9, 2018;

-- a plenary lecture at  the 2019 Canadian Mathematical Society Summer Meeting, Regina, Canada, June 7--10, 2019;

-- the Twenty First Andrzej Jankowski Memorial Lecture, Mathematical Institute of Gdansk University, Gdansk, Poland, May 10, 2019;

-- four one-hour invited lectures at the international conference ``Groups St. Andrews'', Newcastle, UK, July 30-- Aug. 7, 2022; and

--  Colloquium, Department of Mathematics, Princeton University, Feb. 1, 2023.
Some of these results have also been used in graduate courses taught by the PI at Rutgers University,  a guest lecture at Yale University, and
graduate summer schools in the UK, Vietnam, and China.
